title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Wentover to Huntly Burn at two o'clock, and reconnoitred the proposedplantation to be called Jane's Wood.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: _May_ 10.--We went to breakfast at Huntly Burn, and I wandered all themorning in the woods to avoid an English party who came to see thehouse.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: _April_ 22.--Wrote till twelve o'clock, then sallied forth, and walkedto Huntly Burn with Tom; and so, look you, sir, I drove home in thecarriage.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: We came back by Huntly Burn, where the carriagebroke down, and gave us a pretty long walk home.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: I showed him the plantations, going first round theterrace, then to the lake, then came down by the Rhymer's Glen, and tookcarriage at Huntly Burn, almost the grand tour, only we did not walkfrom Huntly Burn.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: _March_ 25.--Hard work still, but went to Huntly Burn on foot, andreturned in the carriage.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: I drove over to Huntly Burn with Anne,then walked through the plantations, with Tom's help to pull me throughthe snow-wreaths.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: I went with all our family to-day to dine as usual at the kind house ofHuntly Burn; but the same cloud which hung over us on Saturday still hadits influence.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: We dined at Huntly Burn.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Went down to Huntly Burn, and dawdled aboutwhile waiting for the carriage to bring me back.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: All the "calliachs"[323] from Huntly Burn are to be here, andAnne wishes we may have enough of dinner.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Walked to Huntly Burn, where I found acertain lady on a visit--so youthy, so beautiful, so strong invoice--with sense and learning--above all, so fond of good conversation,that, in compassion to my eyes, ears, and understanding, I bolted in themiddle of a tremendous shower of rain, and rather chose to be wet to theskin than to be bethumped with words at that rate.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: In the evening we drove to Huntly Burn, andtook tea there.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Then droveto Huntly Burn and called at Chiefswood.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: I never learned grammar; and not only Sir Hugh Evans but even Mrs.Quickly might puzzle me about Giney's case and horum harum horum.[253] Ibelieve the Bailiff in _The Good-natured Man_ is not far wrong when hesays, "One man has one way of expressing himself, and another another,and that is all the difference between them."[254] Went to Huntly Burnto-day and looked at the Colonel's projected approach.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Went at one to Huntly Burn, where Ihad the great pleasure to hear, through a letter from Sir Adam, thatSophia was in health, and Johnnie gaining strength.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: At that hour to-day I drove to Huntly Burn, and walkedhome by one of the hundred and one pleasing paths which I have madethrough the woods I have planted--now chatting with Tom Purdie, whocarries my plaid, and speaks when he pleases, telling long stories ofhits and misses in shooting twenty years back--sometimes chewing the cudof sweet and bitter fancy--and sometimes attending to the humours of twocurious little terriers of the Dandie Dinmont breed, together with anoble wolf-hound puppy which Glengarry has given me to replace Maida.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: They had occupied the house atToftfield (on which Scott at the ladies' request bestowed the name ofHuntly Burn) from the spring of 1818.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: I wrote in the morning at _Woodstock_; walked from one tillfour; was down at Huntly Burn and paid my respects to the ladies.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Called at Huntly Burn, and shook hands with Sir Adam and his Lady justgoing off.

title: The Journal of Sir Walter Scott; From the Original Manuscript at Abbotsford
author: Scott, Walter
